author: Eirian Odalis

text:
Awesome game indeed! 

Before hating on Nintendo, please remember that it was their legal obligation to shut off the download links to AM2R. If they didn't they could lose their ip. So if you want to hate something, hate the copyright and trademarks laws because they are stupid.

Moreover did Nintendo only shut down download links at the official blog and at Metroid database, and not the project itself. So it's still relatively easy to find a download link.
author: YolmzWelra

text:
What good is an IP if they aren't going to do anything with it?




I guess it's a good cash grab. Nintendo doesn't feel the same as it used to be.
author: spoot

text: I don't think Metroid is that good cash grab. The first Metroid Prime is the only Metroid game that has sold really well.
author: YolmzWelra

text: Ethiopian government has a legal obligation to defend their seats and look what happened when they did that!
author: artman40

text: Is that politcs in a youtube comment? Never thought I would see the day.
author: YolmzWelra

text:
Then a non-politics one:

Parents have a right to ground a child for nothing or for anything the parent thinks the child has done wrong. Just because they can, doesn't mean they should.
author: artman40

text:
And what would Nintendo earn by giving up their own ip? An ip they have owned for 30 years.. Of course they will not give up the Metroid ip, hence they need to protect it in order to keep it.

Just because the trademark law is stupid should we still follow it? Unfortunately yes, because civilization wouldn't be civilized without laws. And sometimes laws, such as trademarks, can be stupid, but we still need to follow them.
author: YolmzWelra

text: @YolmzWelra Could you please name any company that has lost their trademark because of fanworks? Also, if you can, can you name a company that has lost money due to losing a trademark because of fanworks?
author: artman40

text:
"Trademark rights can also be lost through improper licensing or assignment. Where the use of a trademark is licensed (for example, to a franchisee) without adequate quality control or supervision by the trademark owner, that trademark will be canceled." from the site https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/domain/tm.htm

What it basically means is that if you don't defend your trademark you may lose it. 

For your question, no I cannot, but I'm not that into companies losing their trademarks. But yet again, I don't think Nintendo wanna chance on losing their ip by letting a big fan game just go under their radar..

And if they are losing money or not. I don't know, but if something, it's probably the opposite in this case. 

I wish the trademark law doesn't exist so Nintendo doesn't need to remove download links to fan projects, but now it does exist and hence Nintendo are forced to do so. However, I think it's nice of Nintendo to not remove the download links until the game's finished. That way people may still find the game somewhere on the interwebz and Nintendo protects their ip. In a way, both are winners, and it wouldn't surprise me if some people at Nintendo are playing AM2R right now and enjoying it.
author: YolmzWelra

text: If the trademark law was changed... it could make everyone happy
author: spoot

text: Indeed!
author: YolmzWelra

text:
I know I'm late as fuck, but Sega gives absolutely no shits about Sonic fangames(except the time they, you know, HIRED the makers of some of them) and yet they still have full control over Sonic.
Now mind you, If fangames could make you lose an IP, I certainly believe the plethora of Sonic fangames would do it rather than a single remake of Metroid 2.
author: The Rape Face

text:
It has been some times since I last commented here, but now I actually doubt Nintendo shut down AM2R in order to protect their ip. Trademark laws should be able to make a company lose their ip, but I doubt this ever happens. However fan games can make the official games sell worse, e.g. I believe AM2R, which is a solid 2D Metroid, made Federation Force, which is a questionable Metroid title, sell worse (it would still flop though, but probably not as bad).

Actually, every fan art, fan remix, fan remake, etc. are illegal to make according to the copyright and trademark laws. Many companies shut down websites that hosted fan art of games and movies during the 90's, but eventually they stopped since fan projects made a solid community, thus making their products sell more. I believe AM2R, just as many Pokemon fan games, was just shut down since it made the official games sell less.
author: YolmzWelra

author: Konata Izumi

text:
I finished it this morning too. I loved it, but I'm disappointed that he has not respected so much the "dark" side of the game. The original version let some clues that Samus isn't heroic so much, some clues that her mission is more a genocide than a real mission to save the world. The player may even feel empathie for the Queen Metroid at the end, since she screams more and more of despair until you finally kill her.
That's a really deep side of the original that as been a little bit forgotten in the remake, that made me understand that a fan remake can't release so easily without the permission of the original producer, because misinterprations of the sense of the game can be made if you only play to the remake.

(still a really really great metroid)
author: Un autre que moi

text: I never thought about that. Samus is obliterating an entire species that deserve to live on their homeland. That darker side was absolutely underdeveloped. Despite that it is a very good metroid game, on par with ZM and Fusion, no doubt about it.

text:

I wouldn't say AM2R is as good as Zero Mission or Fusion but I enjoyed it :).
author: Seki

text:
@giorgioskb I actually believe it stands beside them. Just think about it for a second

1- Is the art style good?
2- What about visuals, samus's suit, environments, enemy designs, ingenuity in locales, Great level design. Is that in the game?
3- What about the soundtrack and themes of every section of the game, did they fit the environment?
4- How were the bosses? Challenging and original? 
5- What about isolation and exploration, did you feel immersed into the world of SR-388?
6- Were new features added into this 2D metroid which didn't appear in the original game?
7- Were you able to go anywhere you wanted and didn't feel the game to be as linear as the gameboy version?

I could go on, but I think those are the most important ones. I said YES to all of those questions. If you do too, then it is one heck of a game, putting it aside of Fusion and ZM.
author: PrimeMujica

text: With no backlight, it really was dark
author: Felipe Tolstenko

text: Means Ultimate Weaon. Against the X-Parasyte ^^
author: Lemonbow

text: +Oceanologue Could you give an example of these clues in the original? I have thought about it being a genocide (and it basically was), and the extinction of metroids brought the X-parasites back so it may not have been the best thing to do. Then again, space pirates could have done something nasty with the Metroids if they ever got their hands on them.
author: Eirian Odalis

text:
There are clues in the global ambiance of the game : the freaky main title theme, the cries of despair from the Queen Metroid.The metroid counter displaying "left" when you press start add some genocide impression. Metroid 2 is also the only metroid metroid where the creatures that appear from the pipes stop appearing before you're fully charged (this particular element highlights the fact you killed them all).

Moreover, if you consider that acid levels are controlled by metroids, you can assume that the falls of acid are correlated with the murder of metroids. The only rise of acid occured at the first appearance of Omega metroid, just after you murdered an alpha metroid (who may have used to be a metroid child protected by his mentor). These elements highlight a defensive position of Metroids, and thus an offensive position of Samus.

The last cave just before the laboratory seems especially empty, I think that the 8 larvae you met in the laboratory were supposed to be in this cave, and had started to flea when you killed the last Omega metroid.

Just consult this article http://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/SRHoliwell/20150130/235329/A_Maze_of_Murderscapes_Metroid_II.php written in a very smart and a very emotional way !

text: Well... this is easily the best fan remake I've ever played. I finished it yesterday after it was released last week (and quickly taken down by Nintendo) and it's so good that I even have to wonder if an official remake would have been as impressive. Almost everything, from the slick controls to the audiovisual presentation, is just right. The new bosses are very good, much better than the various Metroid mini-bosses based on the original GameBoy game. Zero Mission, AM2R and Super Metroid: what an awesome and easily replayable 2D trilogy we now have (+ Fusion). Well done DoctorM64, well done.

text:
@NukeA6 @yamiryushi See, it's a remake of Metroid II. Metroid II is a game that Nintendo is currently selling on their online store, for the 3DS. Why would anyone buy that when there's a much better version available on the PC, for free?

That's the logic behind the takedown. It obviously sucks for everyone. Metroid 2 probably isn't selling like hotcakes anyway, so how much money could they even possibly lose? They could theoretically just leave the remake be, but Nintendo likes to be very careful with its properties, so here we are. But, definitely, it has absolutely nothing to do with Nintendo being "salty" about the Metroid series. It's just a business move.

author: Zaphero

text:
I absolutely loved this game. It was one of the nicest experiences playing a metroid game I ever had. Seeing all kinds of great additions in it like the logbook, the item select (turning on or off some abilities) menu, themes from the prime 2 echoes game, mechanics from Zero Mission, actual enemies from Metroid 2 and much much more. The game's atmosphere is really unique, with great landscapes and sceneries never seen before in any metroid game. 

Despite all that, I would like to point out some of the minor issues/complaints/details that I would suggest to the developer/producer (docm64) to take into consideration if he decides to update the game.... 

1- when you run out of power bombs, the enemies won't give you items to replenish it, you had to go back to a save station to replenish them, which made it a bit annoying, specially when you were next or close to an expansion and you had no power bombs left.
2- The hit box on Omega metroids is ridiculously big and the final boss was easy, too easy in my opinion.. 
3- the death animation on the bigger metroids were a bit anti-climatic, specially the queen 
4- saves stations were kind of far away from some bosses, so you had to play a while whilst heading back again to fight the monster, 
5- Even though I think missiles are VERY important because that is how you kill the metroids and that is how you progress through the game, I think there were too many easy expansions at the start of the game. I had been playing the game for 20 or 30mins and I already had like 100 missiles. If the game is going to give us that much, it would have been better to scatter them around and hide them even more, and therefore make us look for them in a more detailed manner 
6- It would have been great for the queen to summon larval metroids instead of those brown thingies she spits, 
7- Some of the theme transitions weren't that spot on. I remember heading down into the lava area where you encounter the first omega metroid (right before the nest), the music was the same upbeat theme from the previous sector. I mean, you need to build the tension. The only way to do that is with a more frightening and menacing theme, which wasn't the case.

What do you think about that? If you have any other please add to this. Maybe Doctor M64 reads this thread :)
author: PrimeMujica
